thread.name: Setups tasks for display label and computed attribute run indefinitely

messages.content: If you click the dropdown arrow at "Setup triggers of a specific kind", what does that look like?
Do you have any kind of test environment where you also see this behaviour? (trying to figure out how to replicate)
yeah exactly
So a few of the tasks completed successfully where you have more output than you posted above but after a few runs it got stuck again?
it did complete a few of those tasks and now its stuck again on the same flows when i deleted a new branch
so i cleared up the stuck tasks and deleted the keys
But looking at dates the 28th is after you posted this initially..
I'd start by deleting one of those locks to see if the task then continues. As there are a few of them in queue, the same task might run a few times now.
As you can see there's some additional info compared to what you get.
This is from my laptop where the task completes successfully.
and for recovery should i delete the task and locks manually ?
none of these branches have any schema changes

It should be fairly harmless, what I'm wondering is if these locks would have prevented the tasks to be executed in the first place in your environment. I.e. it's after running these that we determine which display labels or HFIDs need to be recalculated, i.e. the node kinds that have had their schema updated in a way that would require a recalculation.
same for the hfid-setup
it does say finished in state completed
not sure if this helps but the last task display-labels-setup-jinja2 has the below output in prefect
In order to move forward there would be two options 1) Remove those locks manually 2). Restart that specific worker.
Yeah, it's expected that they get fired during a branch delete operation so that we can clear out tasks in Prefect if they are there and no longer needed.
all these stuck tasks happen during branch delete operation

The reason for those specific locks is to avoid having multiple workers configure Prefect at the same time, but I don't think that's something that would happen now. I.e the worker that holds the lock would not be in the process of configuring Prefect.

Ok, so then it makes sense that the deadlock task hasn't cleared out those locks given that the worker is up and running. Will have to think about how we end up in this state, my guess is that it has something to do with the locking itself. Just running the task shouldn't take long.
those are the first 2 tasks stuck since i cleared the old tasks manually
the timestamp matches the below two tasks
and the worker id matches one of the active workers currently running
so i checked the keys , the timestamp is 2025-11-28T22:18:56.143587Z
The idea is that those locks would be cleared out by the clean-up-deadlocks flow that runs every minute to check if such locks are stuck.
I'm guessing that those locks are held by a worker that's no longer running. Is that something that you can check?
A GraphQL query like this would show the workers and the status they have.
The content of those keys would match a timestamp and a worker id.
all of the running tasks have been in this state for long

and i do see the lock in redis

```127.0.0.1:6379> keys *action*
1) "lock.global.trigger-rules.configure-action-rules-human_friendly_id"
2) "lock.global.trigger-rules.configure-action-rules-display_label_jinja2"
```
i currently have 15 tasks all related to the above
Am away from the laptop for the week but I'll check and report back

Does all of those setup tasks remained in a stuck state? There in a lock within those tasks https://github.com/opsmill/infrahub/blob/stable/backend/infrahub/trigger/setup.py#L54 but the tasks themselves should complete quite quickly and if the worker that held a previous lock is stopped this should be found by the clean-up-deadlocks job and get released. Can you by any chance see in Redis if you have any such lock?

embeds.title: infrahub/backend/infrahub/trigger/setup.py at stable ¬∑ opsmill/inf...
embeds.description: Infrahub is a graph-based data management platform with built-in version control, CI workflows, peer review, and API access. It‚Äôs purpose-built to power reliable infrastructure automation at scale....

messages.content: Yeah only these ones, rest seem to complete fine

Those tasks should be fired when you delete a branch, the goal of that is to clear out any automations that are no longer needed in Prefect, and potentially update the automations for the default branch to remove branches that were previously excluded. So that the tasks get spawned is expected but they shouldn't keep running. Are these the only ones that get stuck like this?
they spiked when i added a new commit but have gone back to lower utilization now
they are well below the 1 cpu limit right now
What is the CPU load on the task-manager?
no exceptions or error logs in task manager or worker containers
Can you check, if there's any exceptions or error being logged by the task-manager and task-worker containers?
Do the tasks have some logs?
Can you click on the parameters of the task? Can you also check the load in the task-manager container?
think now they will run indefinitely
i created a test branch and then deleted it after a few minutes, it did spawn a few tasks
I just tested that, and it didn't seem to spanw any new tasks
but i think these tasks are started when i delete the branch
dont think so but let me try again
Did you delete the branch when these tasks were still running?
I am on version 1.5.3

I am currently seeing a pattern where whenever i delete a branch the tasks associated with setting up display label and computed attribute run indefinitely. The only way to clear them up is by deleting the tasks from prefect UI.
